Detrean

That is the XXXX that I hear coming out of the conservatives mouths. Appearantly they are so American that they can throw away everything that America was founded on. 
 
 I'm hearing it more and more. Rap hurts our kids and is a pollution we must get rid of it. Again the conservatives show their colors. Your only free as long as your are doing what they want.
 
 Personally I don't like rap. I never listen to it simply because I don't find depth in someone talking about how they have money. Regardless I also think that rappers have every right to say what they want and sell what they want.
 
 Here is my answer to the people that want "offensive" rap made illegal.
 
 DON'T BUY IT!
 
 wow, wasn't that easy? But it's on the radio right? Here is another brilliant idea, DON'T LISTEN TO IT. 
 
 A flick of the wrist or the ability to keep your wallet in your pocket and magicly you don't hear rap. 
 
 Then there is always the arguement that it is hurting their kids. Again I have a solution to that problem. BECOME A PARENT. That's right. I'm asking that you actually act on the family values that you preach. If you do your job as a parent then your kids could not listen to rap and you would be around to enforce that.
 
 Just because you are to lazy to watch over your kids. Doesn't give you the right to dictate what others say. It's called freedom. If you don't like it then move to Iran or North Korea. If you want it illegal then I have news for you. Rap is more American then you....
Wez

Blaming rap is so much easier than being a responsible parent though!
 
 
And last week, I seen a Schwarzaneggar movie
 where he's shootin all sorts of these mother****ers with a uzi
 I sees three little kids, up in the front row,
 screamin "Go," with their 17-year-old Uncle
 I'm like, "Guidance - ain't they got the same moms and dads
 who got mad when I asked if they liked violence?"
 And told me that my tape taught 'em to swear
 What about the make-up you allow your 12-year-old daughter to wear?

 
 -Wez

I'm actually listening to Eminem right now. White America is a truly great track, although I prefer the Slim Shady and Marshall Mathers albums. 
 
 They're a prime example of why rapping isn't just people rapping about how much money they have as well.
 
 I think the evidence rap is harmful is equal to the evidence violent games are harmful - zero.

"They're a prime example of why rapping isn't just people rapping about how much money they have as well."
 
 It isn't just about money. It's about girls, and power as well. There are few rap songs that aren't like that. I personally like old rap more. Back when it wasn't stuck in the rut it is now.
 
 Regardless, my point is that they have a right to say whatever they want.

I personally find a lot of Eminem's stuff very funny, and some of its clever and quite powerful too: take Stan for instance, or Guilty Conscience, or My Fault.
 
 Also, i like the Streets, but they're British rap which is very different. The main theme is 'girls' but only in the sense of the ups and downs of relationships. There are drugs because its a highly accurate representation of the lifestyle and there's one pieec of violence, presented comically 'I'm trying to bring his head down to knee it, but he's got my ear and it's f*cking hurting me...'.

Yeah, rap is all about bitches and bling...
 
 
Yo, it's one universal law but two sides to every story
 Three strikes and you be in for life, mandatory
 Four MC's murdered in the last four years
 I ain't tryin to be the fifth one, the millenium is here
 Yo it's 6 Million Ways to Die, from the seven deadly thrills
 Eight year-olds gettin found with 9 mils
 It's 10 P.M., where your seeds at? What's the deal
 He on the hill puffin krill to keep they belly filled
 Light in the XXX with heavy steel, sights on the pretty **** in life
 Young soldiers tryin to earn they next stripe
 When the average minimum wage is $5.15
 You best believe you gotta find a new ground to get cream
 The white unemployment rate, is nearly more than triple for black
 so frontliners got they gun in your back
 Bubblin crack, jewel theft and robbery to combat poverty
 and end up in the global jail economy
 Stiffer stipulations attached to each sentence

 And even if you get out of prison still livin
 join the other five million under state supervision
 This is business, no faces just lines and statistics
 from your phone, your zip code, to S-S-I digits
 The system break man child and women into figures
 Two columns for who is, and who ain't niggaz
 Numbers is hardly real and they never have feelings
 but you push too hard, even numbers got limits
 Why did one straw break the camel's back? Here's the secret:
 the million other straws underneath it - it's all mathematics
Desaix

Fishbulb has hit the nail on the head.I'm glad somebody brought up Mos Def before I did(or Talib Kweli,Common,The Roots,Nas,AZ,Dead Prez etc).No rap is not all about girls,power and money.Thats trash and the typical idea you get from watching MTV.There is a huge amount and I mean huge amount of brilliant Hip-Hop with talented and intelligent rappers.Simply because MTV tells you 50 cent or Game(both mediocre) are the best rappers out there and that 'Candy Shop'(good beats,not much else) is the epitome of Hip-Hop doesn't make it so.It simly means that the music industry never changes,forever people that can be 'sold' are out on the TV rather then those with talent,not just with Hip-Hop but on rock,metal etc.
 
 Despite being a massive Punk,Metal,Classic,Jazz etc fan I can easily say that Hip-Hop has tracks better then any other genres like Nas's Life's a Bitch,AZ's Rather Unique,The Roots How They Do and Talib Kweli's Good Mourning.
zachvac

While I agree it should be allowed, I would like to point out that it is virtually impossible to not expose a kid to rap. At school every lunch we have music almost all of which is rap. I really have no problem with it and think kids should be exposed to that sort of thing. A really responsible parent is one that exposes them to things such as this and explains that just because it talks about stuff, doesn't mean it's true.
 
 
 Anyway... I don't particularly like rap, although I don't hate it. But when I'm at home, I don't turn on a rap station and I don't own a rap CD, if you don't like it, don't listen, and kids will be exposed to it anyway, may as well do it while they have parenting to help them understand.
